item.title: Assassin's Creed: Black Flag Remake Seemingly Confirmed by PEGI Rating
item.content:encoded:
A PEGI rating has been spotted for something called Assassin's Creed: Black Flag Resynced, which appears to pretty much confirm the long-mooted remake or remaster of the piratical open-world adventure.

The rating, which puts the game at 18 for "violence", "bad language", and "in-game purchases" (because of course; this is Ubisoft we're talking about, after all) was spotted by Gematsu, but it's not the first we've heard of a potential Black Flag remake or remaster.

A couple of weeks ago, Reddit user thequaliti spotted text pointing to Black Flag Resynced within the localization table of Assassin's Creed Shadows. Essentially, the text is a quick disclaimer discussing "creative liberties" taken with history to create the game, but it's another pretty strong piece of evidence, too.

There's precedent for this, too; in June last year, Ubisoft CEO Yves Guillemot promised that "some remakes" of titles in the Assassin's Creed series were on the way, and that these projects would "revisit some of the games [Ubisoft has] created in the past and modernize them".

Assassin's Creed: Black Flag seems like a pretty solid candidate to kick off Ubisoft's slate of Assassin's Creed remakes, especially given the grim fate of the studio's other foray into nautical adventuring in recent years.

Still, I'd argue that remaking the original game, or perhaps Assassin's Creed III, would be a better shout. These are games with (in my eyes, at least) very clear flaws, so giving them another try and sanding down some of the more troublesome edges makes a lot of sense to me.

Black Flag, by contrast, is still a very good game by today's standards, and as an avowed RPG-element-Assassin's Creed hater, I'm worried Ubisoft is going to drown the seafaring, swashbuckling classic in gear scores and incremental loot.

Given the increasing buzz around the so-called Assassin's Creed: Black Flag Resynced, it may well be that we can expect an official announcement at The Game Awards, which is set to reward some of its nominees with shiny trophies later this week.

We'll have to wait and see whether that announcement surfaces or not. Stay tuned for more, and in the meantime, you can revisit the original Black Flag right now on PC, PlayStation 4, Xbox One, and Nintendo Switch.

Joe has been writing for TechRaptor for several years, and in those years has learned a lot about the gaming industry and its foibles. He’s originally an… More about Joseph

item.title: Phasmophobia Winter's Jest Event Brings Festive Fun Next Week
item.content:encoded:
Phasmophobia developer Kinetic Games has revealed that the multiplayer ghost-hunting horror title's Winter's Jest event is set to return next week, bringing map makeovers, new rewards, and more.

As revealed in a press release, Winter's Jest, which is one of Phasmophobia's recurring holiday events, makes its triumphant return on December 16th, and several of the game's maps will receive festive makeovers to celebrate the event, including the new Nell's Diner location.

Once again, Krampus will be awakening from his lengthy sleep, and it'll be up to you find his jack-in-the-box, which will be "hidden across a rotating selection of event maps". Successfully completing this challenge will net you "frost-acular rewards".

Rewards include a new upgradable trophy, as well as a new ID card and badge. You will, of course, also get the chance to explore festive versions of maps including the aforementioned Nell's Diner, as well as Grafton and Bleasdale Farmhouses and more.

Elsewhere in Phasmophobia news, it was announced back in June that horror movie production studio Blumhouse is working on a movie adaptation of the game, with James Wan's production company Atomic Monster also set to co-produce.

If you're unfamiliar with Phasmophobia, it's a multiplayer ghost-hunting horror game in which your goal is to enter a series of haunted locations in order to obtain evidence of the type of ghost that's haunting them.

To do so, you and your team will have access to a range of gadgets, some of which will be more useful than others for specific situations. As you play, you'll upgrade your gadgets and get to know each ghost type better.

You can check out Phasmophobia right now on PC, PlayStation 5, and Xbox Series X|S. The game's Winter's Jest event kicks off across all platforms on December 16th, so make sure you and your squad are ready for that.
